description: From Ancient Greek πᾶν (pân, “all”) + ὀπτικός (optikós, “visible”). Coined by English philosopher Jeremy Bentham in 1791.

entries.meaning: A type of prison where all the cells are visible from the center, particularly if it is not possible for those in a cell to know if they are being watched.
(figurative, by extension) A place in which people are subject to constant surveillance at totalitarian command.
examples: Perhaps the construction of such a genetic panopticon is wise. But I doubt that the proud men who wrote the charter of our liberties would have been so eager to open their mouths for royal inspection.

entries.meaning: A room for the exhibition of novelties.
